author: @coreyms
text: Hey everyone! I hope everyone finds this video helpful. I wanted to make this video shorter, but I really wanted to highlight all the different ways we can update our rows and cover the apply, map, and applymap methods in as much detail as I could. In the next video, we'll be learning how to add and remove rows/columns. It will be much shorter. I should have that video out next week. I hope you all have a great weekend!

author: @daviskipchirchir1357
text: Brilliant work man.   Just adding that the method df.at() is inherited from C++ vector container. This seems to be true because Numpy, the base class for Pandas, was written in C++ for speed purposes. So as Pandas is a layer on top of Numpy, which is a layer on top of C++ containers, then the method must have been transferred from the containers all the way up the stack to Pandas.

author: @niklasalexanderBjerkeland
text: For those who are interested, used data analysis in Chatgpt 4 to create some mock data and run a comparison .at crushes .loc at performance :   n a performance comparison between the .loc and .at methods for modifying a single value in a large dataset (10 million cells), the results are as follows:  Time taken using .loc: 0.0789 0.0789 seconds Time taken using .at: 0.0077 0.0077 seconds  As someone who often modifies huge datasets with million of rows, it is nice to know. Guess it is of interest to other people here as well

author: @anthonyerdenetuguldur5609
text: Thanks @Corey Schafer for putting this great Panda's Tutorials together.   on 11:00, regarding .at indexer vs .loc,   I found that the .at indexer is more optimal than .loc if you need to change a variable in a particular (single) index location. The .loc method enables change in multiple rows and columns (more versatile) hence a little slower than .at method.

author: @tekrunner987
text: For anyone watching this after August 2023, in v2.1.0 Pandas renamed DataFrame.applymap() to just DataFrame.map(). So map() now works for both Series and Dataframes, and applies its function to every cell of data in both cases.

author: @crunchycho
text: @Corey Schafer hey corey, took a minute to do some research that found that .at is only for getting single values given row & column. It is much much faster than loc. Also preserves datatype. So if you have an INT column and feel in a float, it'll get truncated to its INT version. Thanks for the videos!

author: @simonerogato3779
text: Nice video! I would like to point out that in my personal testings the AT method is between 10-20 times faster then the LOC., but there is a MASSIVE problem with that function. If you try to use the AT method and update a int value with a float value, it will be SILENTLY casted to int if the column is INT only. This can seriously damage some Datasets with no alerts. If you use the LOC method instead, the entire COLUMN values will be casted to float. Thanks a lot for your videos Mr. Schafer, I'm learning a lot !

author: @reydman08
text: Corey, Thank you so much for your videos! They are simply Brilliant :)   A few quick notes: 1) at is much much faster comparing to loc.  Here is the proof: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37216485/pandas-at-versus-loc  2) map method can work with NaN values just like replace. We just need to use na_action=''ignore' argument

author: @TynOng
text: .at supposed to be faster than .loc where you only need to access one row. But someone in stackoverflow question, noticed (Pandas 0.20) that .at preserves the data type where .loc convert it. e.g existing column as int values, you assign float, .at convert your float to int (precision loss) where .loc converts the column into float I tested in Pandas 1.0.3 and got same result

author: @coreyms
text: Hey everyone! I hope everyone finds this video helpful. I wanted to make this video shorter, but I really wanted to highlight all the different ways we can update our rows and cover the apply, map, and applymap methods in as much detail as I could. In the next video, we'll be learning how to add and remove rows/columns. It will be much shorter. I should have that video out next week. I hope you all have a great weekend!
